results.title: The Thin Blue Line
results.brief_description: Errol Morris’s unique documentary dramatically re-enacts the crime scene and investigation of a police officer’s murder in Dallas in a film that the Criterion Collection describes as “a work of meticulous journalism and gripping drama”.

constellations_primary.name: Presumption of guilt
constellations_primary.description: A Constellation looking at true crime documentaries, the nature of innocence and prejudice.

constellations_other.name: Reasonable doubt
constellations_other.description: Factual media has the power to reframe information and put forth new, persuasive arguments.  For the criminal justice system, where convictions are made based on arguments being convincing beyond a reasonable doubt, True Crime media has the ability to create doubt, right the wrongs of the justice system, and shed new light on closed cases.

constellations_other.name: Reconstructing reality
constellations_other.description: While documentary pertains to be about the truth, many filmmakers and artists have used ingenious reconstructions to represent an abstracted honesty.

results.description: In this film Randall Adams, serving a life sentence for the murder of a police officer, swears that he did not commit the crime. In the way he dramatises the quest for evidence Morris emphasises the contradictions in the testimony of key witnesses and legal figures involved with the case and the inconclusiveness of the evidence which served to convict Adams, in what becomes an ironic reflection upon the nature of knowledge and truth. As Bill Nichols points out, Morris’s strategy is the converse of that of documentaries which subordinate their own textual voice to that of the witnesses. In the Thin Blue Line the textual voice actually threatens to overwhelm the discrete voices of the social actors (including that of Adams himself) with its own message about the problematics of representations.
description_for_label: In this film Randall Adams, serving a life sentence for the murder of a police officer, swears that he did not commit the crime. In the Thin Blue Line the textual voice actually threatens to overwhelm the discrete voices of the social actors (including that of Adams himself) with its own message about the problematics of representations.

results.title: The Green mile
results.creator_credit: Frank Darabont, David Valdes, Darkwoods Productions and Castle Rock Entertainment
results.brief_description: Set in 1935, inmates at the Cold Mountain Correctional Facility call Death Row “The Green Mile” because of the dark green linoleum that tiles the floor. The story is told as a memoir by Paul Edgecombe (Tom Hanks), now living in an elderly care facility and revisiting his exceptional life, who was head guard on the Green Mile whilst the incidents being recounted occur. A new inmate is brought into his custody: John Coffey (Michael Clarke Duncan), an African American convicted of the brutal murders of young twin white girls. Despite his immense size and fearsome reputation, Coffey seems to be a kind and well-mannered person with a very child-like manner about him. Soon Edgecombe and two of his fellow guards notice that he has the ability to perform miraculous cures, prompting the guards to wonder how such a man could be guilty of the heinous crimes he is charged with. The cast also include James Cromwell as the warden, Sam Rockwell and Graham Greene as inmates awaiting their time in the electric chair, and Harry Dean Stanton as a clever trustee. This film is based on the 1996 serialized novel by Stephen King.

results.title: The Chinese bungalow
results.creator_credit: George King and British Lion Film Corp
results.brief_description: Based on the Matheson Lang and Marion Osmond stage drama about a Chinese merchant who plots to kill the lover of his English wife. Stars Paul Lukas, Jane Baxter, Robert Douglas, Kay Walsh, Wallace Douglas, Jerry Verno. Photography by Hone Glendinning. Music by Jack Beaver. Edited by Jack Harris. Art direction by Philip Bawcombe.

results.title: Lock, stock and two smoking barrels [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Guy Ritchie, Matthew Vaughn, Ska Films and Summit Entertainment
results.brief_description: When four small time London cons pool their savings for a high-rolling illegal card game with local crime boss Hatchet Harry, things don’t quite go as confidently anticipated. The four friends end up owing him half a million pounds with only a week to pay it off under threat of systematic loss of fingers if they fail to do so. As they engage in robbery, deception and double crossing involving their criminal next door neighbours, powerful drug barons and Harry himself to get the money, circumstances spiral surrealistically out of their control. The situation is further complicated by confusion over two valuable antique guns that Hatchet Harry has purchased, and which are mistakenly directed for use in pulling a ‘job’. The four hapless friends muddle through the seedy underside of London and an unwittingly created gang war in a collection of comic moments and misunderstandings balanced seamlessly with more serious elements. This is a tightly structured film with a cleverly twisted plot and striking rhythmic visuals and editing that, combined with the soundtrack, can be likened to the best of music videos. Cast includes Jason Flemyng, Dexter Fletcher, Nick Moran, Jason Stratham and Steven Mackintosh.

results.title: Two hands [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Gregor Jordan, Marian MacGowan, Meridian Films and CML
results.brief_description: Set in Sydney’s King’s Cross, 19 year old Jimmy (Heath Ledger) finds himself in debt to a local gangster, Pando, played by perennial Australian actor Bryan Brown, when a simple job goes wrong. Jimmy’s life depends on his locating the $10,000 he has lost. As his scheme to replace the cash is played out, two street kids are enjoying a shopping spree with the original loot. The black humour of the film progressively darkens as the story unfolds. Rose Byrne co-stars as country girl, Alex, who becomes involved with Jimmy and his increasingly dire situation.

results.title: Waking Ned Devine
results.creator_credit: Kirk Jones, Glynis Murray, Richard Holmes, Overseas Filmgroup, Mainstream S.A., Gruber Brothers, Can and Bonaparte Films
results.brief_description: Kirk Jones makes his directorial debut with a charming story about the small Irish village of Tullymore (Tulaigh More) where one of the 52 inhabitants wins the lottery jackpot of nearly seven million pounds. When no-one claims it the town goes on a search to find out why. What they find is old Ned Devine dead, a smile on his face, clutching the winning ticket. In Ireland the lottery winnings must be claimed by the purchaser - so local schemer Jackie O’Shea (Ian Bannen) hatches a scheme to impersonate the recently departed Ned. What ensues is a community coming together in the hopes of getting the money to split it 51 ways, what they learn is the importance of friendship and the true value of money.

results.title: Ladybird, ladybird
results.creator_credit: Ken Loach, Sally Hibbin and Film Four International
results.brief_description: A single mother struggles against the British social service system and her own troubled past in director Ken Loach’s brutally realistic drama. Coming from a background of abuse and poverty, the hardened Maggie (Crissy Rock) has already suffered through a series of painful romances when she falls for the caring Jorge (Vladimir Vega) and they begin a loving but turbulent relationship. Their situation takes a turn for the worse when Maggie becomes pregnant, her troubled past leaving her branded an unfit mother by the government with four other children already in foster care. Determined to keep their child, Maggie and Jorge begin a difficult fight against government bureaucracy, made all the more difficult by Maggie’s volatile temperament. This is the story of a woman whose fierce maternal instincts are not enough to placate a society that places conformity over uncontrolled and unconditional love.

results.title: Better than chocolate
results.creator_credit: Anne Wheeler, Sharon McGowan, Telefilm Canada, Race Films and British Columbia Film
results.brief_description: Maggie has flunked law school and is working for uptight Frances, who runs a gay bookshop in Vancouver. Kim is a van-dwelling artist. When they meet it is love at first sight. To avoid confrontation with her mother, Maggie makes up a success story and tells her that she’s living in a beautiful apartment ( she is - it’s just that she’s housesitting for a woman who runs Safer Sex With Latex workshops). Just at their relationship is blossoming Maggie learns that her mother and brother (who have no idea about her sexuality) are planning to come and stay with her. This confronting movie is about the problems young lesbians experience coming out and facing their parents (and society) and realizing that in the long run being a lesbian is not the worst problem one can have.

results.title: The Outsiders
results.creator_credit: Francis Ford Coppola, Gray Frederickson, Fred Roos, Pony Boy, Warner Bros Pictures and Zoetrope Studios
results.brief_description: The first of two films made by Coppola in 1983 and based on novels by youth fiction writer S.E. Hinton (‘The Outsiders’ was her first novel, published when she was just seventeen). Like ‘Rumble Fish’, ‘The Outsiders’ was a rites-of-passage novel that focused on the lives of disenfranchised urban male youth. Set in 1966 in Tulsa, Oklahoma, it follows the lives of the members of two rival teenage street gangs; the middle-class Greasers and the working-class Socs. When Ponyboy, the youngest of three orphaned boys who hang out with the Greasers, and his friend Johnny, are involved in a deadly confrontation with the Socs one night, the two are forced to hide out and reconsider the direction their lives are taking. Cast includes Matt Dillon, Ralph Macchio, Patrick Swayze, Rob Lowe, Emilio Estevez, Tom Cruise and Tom Waits. Original music by Carmine Coppola.

results.title: Caught
results.creator_credit: Max Ophuls, Wolfgang Reinhardt and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Smith Ohrig, played by Robert Ryan, is a hedonistic, charming playboy (loosely based on Howard Hughes). Impulsively marrying ambitious, idealistic wanna-be model Leonora Eames (Barbara Bel Geddes), Ohrig keeps her a virtual prisoner in his palatial mansion, tormenting her with twisted mind games while he continues his premarital playboy activities. Coming to the realization that wealth and creature comforts are no substitute for stability, Leonora takes a job in the offices of society doctor Larry Quinada (James Mason). When Leonora finds comfort in the arms of the doctor, Ohrig becomes intent on destroying her. This is a classic film noir story of a young girl’s dream turning to nightmare.
